results.title: Danger! Radio active waste
results.creator_credit: Joan Konner, Films Incorporated and NBC News
results.brief_description: Progress is in a dead heat with destruction as the nuclear industry tries to keep ahead of its own waste, all of which is radioactive and therefore highly dangerous. The horrors of radioactive overexposure - possible genetic damage, increased incidences of cancer and leukemia, and others, are further heightened by an apparent inability of both government and industry to solve the nuclear waste disposal problem.

results.title: Danger in the dark
results.brief_description: Describes some special precautions necessary when driving at night - the time when more than half Australia’s road accidents occur.

results.title: The Dancing class
results.brief_description: Captures the atmosphere of dedication at the Robert Pomie Ballet School. Shows a ballet class at work featuring seventeen year old Sylvia Polvolgyi. Taken in sequence the film shows the daily routine of the cleaner at work in the studio, the girls arriving, changing and going to the bar to warm up and finishing with an adagio and allegro. Camera by Tom Cowan and Nigel Buesst; music by George Dreyfus. (Gold Award, Documentary Section, 1964 Australian Film Awards)

results.title: A Dancer's world
results.creator_credit: Peter Glushanok, Nathan Kroll and WQED
results.brief_description: Martha Graham, noted choreographer and modern dancer, discusses the dancer as a creative artist. She explains the dancer’s craft as members of her company illustrate her theories in a dance choreographed by Ms Graham especially for the film. Woven into the movements of the dance are all the basic techniques required by the modern dancer.

results.title: Dancers of the sea
results.creator_credit: Genevieve Hamon, Jean Painleve and Les Documents Cinematographiques
results.brief_description: Made by Painleve, famous French scientific documentary filmmaker, this film is a close study of a number of types of starfish. It deals with eating methods, breeding habits, movement on the ocean floor and in the water of some beautiful sea creatures. The film uses high speed and microcinematography to great advantage in this study of marine life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Genevieve Hamon, Jean Painleve and Les Documents Cinematographiques

results.title: Dance squared = Ronde carree
results.creator_credit: Rene Jodoin, Frank Spiller and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film is an encounter with geometrical shapes which children can readily understand and enjoy. As the title suggests “Dance Squared” employs movement, colour and music to explore the symmetries of the square. Every movement of the square and its components presents an opportunity to observe its geometrical properties in a way that is intriguing to young minds. With basic concepts firmly grasped, the young student is then prepared to experiment on his own. No dialogue, set to square dance music, suitable for all ages. (Five awards, including Chicago and Toronto.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rene Jodoin, Frank Spiller and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Dance of the shells = Tanz der muscheln
results.brief_description: The many shaped and many textured world of shells from all over the oceans is observed under changing lights and in varied patterns of movement. The accompanying music is composed of electronically produced sound. Beautifully photographed and dramatically lit - a very striking film.

results.title: The Dance of the angels: ceramic sculptures of John Perceval
results.creator_credit: Tim Burstall, Patrick Ryan and Eltham Films
results.brief_description: Camera movement and film editing are combined to animate the ceramic figurines of John Perceval. He created his angels “more or less as symbols of the world’s survival.” An intangible element common to all Perceval’s angels is their spirit of humanity. These ceramic sculptures are disting- uished by their beautiful modelling, and their lustrous red copper glaze with its uncanny depth and beauty. Perceval does not devote himself exclusively to ceramic sculpture; he gives equal time to painting and has won the McCaughey and Vizard-Whollohan Prizes, and shared the Wynne Prize in 1961. Photography by Gerard Vanderberg; music by Dorian Le Gallienne.
